qas.question: How did Frederick II of Prussia respond to news of British and French clashes in North America?

answers.text: he led Prussian troops across the border of Saxony

qas.question: What country was Saxony aligned with?

answers.text: Saxony, one of the small German states in league with Austria

qas.question: Fpr what possession of Prussia was the Saxony invasion a distraction?

answers.text: pre-emption of an anticipated Austro-French invasion of Silesia

qas.question: What was one goal of the invasion of Saxony?

answers.text: he would seize Saxony and eliminate it as a threat to Prussia

qas.question: What was another goal of the invasion of Saxony?

answers.text: to advance into Bohemia where he might set up winter quarters at Austria's expense

context: Frederick II of Prussia had received reports of the clashes in North America and had formed an alliance with Great Britain. On 29 August 1756, <a0_0>he led Prussian troops across the border of <a1_0>Saxony<a0_0/>, one of the small German states in league with Austria<a1_0/>. He intended this as a bold <a2_0>pre-emption of an anticipated Austro-French invasion of Silesia<a2_0/>. He had three goals in his new war on Austria. First, <a3_0>he would seize Saxony and eliminate it as a threat to Prussia<a3_0/>, then using the Saxon army and treasury to aid the Prussian war effort. His second goal was <a4_0>to advance into Bohemia where he might set up winter quarters at Austria's expense<a4_0/>. Thirdly, he wanted to invade Moravia from Silesia, seize the fortress at Olmütz, and advance on Vienna to force an end to the war.
